title: Myasthenia Gravis - Exacerbation/Crisis
scope: ** Acute exacerbation and myasthenic crisis in adults with known or suspected myasthenia gravis. Covers respiratory monitoring, emergent immunotherapy (IVIG/PLEX), cholinesterase inhibitor management, distinguishing myasthenic from cholinergic crisis, and medications to avoid. Excludes new diagnosis workup (see MG - New Diagnosis template), Lambert-Eaton syndrome, and chronic stable management.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline; infection screen (common trigger); leukocytosis suggests infection
Electrolytes, renal/hepatic function for medication dosing; hypokalemia worsens weakness
Hypomagnesemia worsens NMJ transmission; CONTRAINDICATED to give IV Mg in MG crisis
Essential/Core Labs.target: Confirm normal BEFORE any magnesium replacement

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Thyroid disease coexists in 10-15% of MG; thyrotoxicosis precipitates crisis
If febrile; infection is #1 trigger for crisis
Affects treatment choices; MG can fluctuate in pregnancy
Coagulation before procedures; PLEX circuit anticoagulation
Respiratory failure assessment; hypercapnia is LATE finding — do not wait for this

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Confirm diagnosis if not previously tested; positive in 85% generalized MG
Additional sensitivity when binding Ab equivocal
If AChR negative; MuSK-positive MG has different treatment implications (poor response to pyridostigmine, PLEX preferred over IVIG)
Associated with thymoma; especially in young patients
Differentiate bacterial infection trigger from other causes of decompensation
Aspiration pneumonia, atelectasis; baseline for ventilator
Check azathioprine metabolites (6-TGN), mycophenolate levels, tacrolimus levels if on these agents

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Associated with myocarditis in MG; cardiac risk stratification
Hypogammaglobulinemia from rituximab or chronic IVIG; IgA deficiency before IVIG

Essential/First-line.target: Arrhythmia, myocarditis (rare but reported in MG, especially anti-Kv1.4+)
FVC >20 mL/kg; NIF more negative than -30 cmH2O

Extended.timing: During admission if not recently done
If diagnosis not confirmed; avoid during acute crisis (deferred to stable phase)
Extended.target: Decremental response >10% at 2-3 Hz in affected muscle

Extended.timing: Most sensitive test (95-99%); defer to outpatient stable phase
If altered mental status to rule out other causes
Extended.target: Normal (MG does not affect brain parenchyma)

Rare/Specialized.timing: If cardiac symptoms or anti-Kv1.4 positive

Acute/Emergent.indication: First-line immunotherapy for myasthenic crisis or severe exacerbation

dosing.instructions: 0.4 g/kg/day IV x 5 days (total 2 g/kg) OR 1 g/kg/day x 2 days (faster option). Start within 24h of crisis recognition

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: IgA deficiency (anaphylaxis risk — use IgA-depleted product); renal failure; thrombotic risk
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Vital signs q15min first infusion; renal function daily; headache (aseptic meningitis); thrombotic events

Acute/Emergent.indication: First-line immunotherapy for crisis; preferred in MuSK-positive MG

dosing.instructions: 5 exchanges over 10-14 days (every other day); 1-1.5 plasma volumes per exchange. PREFERRED for MuSK-positive MG. Faster onset than IVIG (days vs 1-2 weeks)

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Hemodynamic instability, severe sepsis, heparin allergy, poor vascular access
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: BP continuous during exchange; Ca2+ (citrate toxicity); fibrinogen; electrolytes; line infection

Acute/Emergent.indication: Respiratory failure from myasthenic crisis (FVC <20 mL/kg)

dosing.instructions: Indications: FVC <20 mL/kg, NIF >-30 cmH2O (weaker), >30% FVC decline, clinical distress, inability to handle secretions. Use NON-DEPOLARIZING agents at REDUCED DOSE (MG patients are sensitive). Avoid succinylcholine (unpredictable response)

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Ventilator per ICU protocol; daily SBT when improving

Acute/Emergent.indication: Reduce secretions and prevent cholinergic complications during intubation

dosing.instructions: HOLD cholinesterase inhibitors during intubation/crisis — excess cholinergic stimulation increases secretions and complicates ventilator management. Resume at reduced dose during weaning

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Secretion management; restart when extubation approaching

dosing.instructions: As needed for SpO2 <94%

Acute/Emergent.indication: Maintenance hydration and renal protection during IVIG

dosing.instructions: NS maintenance; hydration for IVIG renal protection
Resume at 30 mg PO TID during recovery; titrate by 30 mg/dose q3-5 days to 60 mg PO q4-6h; max 120 mg q4h (rarely needed). Take 30-60 min before meals for dysphagia

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Cholinergic crisis (excessive dosing), mechanical bowel obstruction
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: GI symptoms (diarrhea, cramping, salivation = cholinergic excess); reduce dose if muscarinic symptoms

dosing.instructions: 1-2 mg PO BID-TID; or 0.2 mg IV PRN for excessive secretions

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Heart rate; urinary retention; dry mouth

dosing.instructions: 650-1000 mg PO q6h; max 4g/day
4 mg IV/PO q6h PRN
25-50 mg IV/PO 30 min before IVIG infusion
40 mg SC daily
Apply bilaterally on admission
40 mg IV/PO daily
Per institutional protocol; target glucose 140-180 mg/dL

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Blood glucose q6h or more frequent

Second-line/Refractory.indication: High-dose immunosuppression for severe or refractory MG exacerbation

dosing.instructions: 1000 mg IV daily x 3-5 days. CAUTION: steroids can transiently worsen MG in first 5-10 days — only initiate in monitored setting with respiratory support available. Some centers use slow oral prednisone uptitration instead

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: FVC/NIF closely; glucose q6h; BP; GI prophylaxis

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Oral immunosuppression with gradual uptitration to reduce transient worsening

dosing.instructions: Start 10-20 mg PO daily; increase by 10 mg every 3-5 days to target 1 mg/kg/day (max 60-80 mg); maintain for 4-8 weeks, then slow taper over months

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Glucose, BP, weight, bone density, mood; GI prophylaxis; PJP prophylaxis if prolonged high-dose

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Inadequate response to initial immunotherapy course

doseOptions.orderSentence: Second course IVIG or PLEX N/A -

dosing.instructions: Repeat standard dosing if inadequate response to first course; wait 2-4 weeks between courses
dosing.orderSentence: Second course IVIG or PLEX N/A -

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Refractory AChR-positive generalized MG unresponsive to standard therapy

dosing.instructions: 900 mg IV q1 week x 4 weeks, then 1200 mg IV q2 weeks; for AChR-positive refractory generalized MG

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Unresolved Neisseria meningitidis infection; must vaccinate ≥2 weeks before starting

Second-line/Refractory.indication: AChR-positive generalized MG with insufficient response to conventional therapy

dosing.instructions: 10 mg/kg IV weekly x 4 weeks per cycle; repeat cycles based on clinical response; for AChR-positive generalized MG

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: IgG levels (target reduction); infection signs; CBC

dosing.instructions: 375 mg/m2 IV weekly x 4 weeks OR 1000 mg IV x 2 doses 2 weeks apart; especially effective in MuSK-positive MG

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Active infection, hepatitis B (reactivation risk — screen first)
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: CD20 count, immunoglobulins q3 months; hepatitis B screening; PML risk (rare)

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.indication: First-line steroid-sparing agent for long-term MG immunosuppression

dosing.instructions: Start 50 mg PO daily; increase by 50 mg every 1-2 weeks to target 2-3 mg/kg/day; onset of effect 6-12 months

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.contraindications: TPMT deficiency; pregnancy; concurrent allopurinol (dose reduce by 75%)
Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.monitoring: CBC weekly x 4 weeks, then biweekly x 2 months, then monthly; LFTs monthly x 3, then q3 months

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.indication: Steroid-sparing immunosuppression for generalized MG maintenance

dosing.instructions: Start 500 mg PO BID; increase to 1000 mg PO BID after 2 weeks; max 1500 mg BID; onset 6-12 months

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.monitoring: CBC q1 week x 1 month, then biweekly x 2 months, then monthly; LFTs q3 months

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.indication: Alternative steroid-sparing agent for MG when first-line agents fail

dosing.instructions: 3 mg PO daily in 2 divided doses; target trough 5-10 ng/mL; onset 3-6 months

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.monitoring: Trough level q1 week initially, then monthly; Cr, K+, glucose, BP; drug interactions (CYP3A4)

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.indication: Second-line steroid-sparing immunosuppression for refractory MG

dosing.instructions: Start 2-3 mg/kg/day PO in 2 divided doses; target trough 100-200 ng/mL; onset 3-6 months

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.monitoring: Trough levels, Cr, BP, Mg, lipids monthly

Referrals & Consults.indication: All myasthenic crisis; treatment decisions; medication management
Thymoma evaluation; thymectomy planning (if not previously done)
Dysphagia evaluation; aspiration prevention (bulbar weakness common in crisis)
Prevent deconditioning; safe mobilization; fall prevention
ADL assessment; energy conservation techniques; adaptive equipment
Medication reconciliation — review ALL medications for MG-unsafe drugs
Discharge planning; support resources; insurance for IVIG/PLEX
Goals of care discussion for refractory or elderly patients
If infection trigger unclear or complex; immunosuppressed patient management
If concurrent thyroid disease; steroid-induced diabetes management

Patient Instructions.item: Call 911 / Return to ED if: increasing difficulty breathing, trouble swallowing, choking on food or saliva, unable to hold head up, rapidly worsening weakness
Carry MG crisis card / MedicAlert bracelet at all times
Bring complete medication list to every medical visit; alert ALL providers about MG diagnosis
NEVER take antibiotics, pain medications, or new prescriptions without checking with neurology
Take pyridostigmine 30-60 minutes before meals for best swallowing function
Avoid extreme heat (worsens weakness), overexertion, and sleep deprivation
Report any new medication prescribed by other providers to your neurologist
Infection prevention: hand hygiene, avoid sick contacts, up-to-date vaccinations (inactivated only if immunosuppressed; NO live vaccines)
Follow-up with neurology 1-2 weeks post-discharge; sooner if symptoms worsen

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Infection avoidance (number one trigger for crisis)
COVID-19 vaccination (inactivated/mRNA; coordinate timing with immunosuppression cycle)
NO live vaccines if on immunosuppression (MMR, varicella, live zoster, yellow fever)
Moderate exercise as tolerated; avoid overexertion; rest periods during activity
Heat avoidance (hot weather, hot tubs, saunas worsen NMJ transmission)
Eye protection (sunglasses, patching for diplopia; artificial tears for incomplete lid closure)

differential.features: EXCESSIVE pyridostigmine; salivation, lacrimation, urination, diarrhea, emesis (SLUDE); miosis; fasciculations; weakness WORSENS with additional pyridostigmine
differential.tests: Hold pyridostigmine — if strength improves, cholinergic; if worsens, myasthenic crisis. Clinical distinction is key

differential.features: Ascending paralysis, areflexia, albuminocytologic dissociation, preceding infection, no fatigability
differential.tests: NCS/EMG (demyelinating neuropathy vs NMJ); LP (elevated protein); no response to pyridostigmine

differential.features: Proximal weakness IMPROVES with repeated use; autonomic dysfunction (dry mouth); associated with small cell lung cancer; hyporeflexia
differential.tests: VGCC antibodies; NCS (incremental response with high-rate repetitive stimulation — opposite of MG)

differential.features: Descending paralysis (cranial → limbs); dilated pupils; foodborne or wound exposure; autonomic dysfunction
differential.tests: Stool/serum botulinum toxin; NCS (incremental); clinical history

differential.features: Progressive weakness without fluctuation; upper AND lower motor neuron signs; no fatigability pattern; fasciculations
differential.tests: NCS/EMG (denervation); no response to IVIG/PLEX; no AChR antibodies

differential.features: Acute onset; cranial nerve findings; crossed findings (ipsilateral cranial nerve + contralateral limb); no fatigability
CNS symptoms (optic neuritis, sensory level, cerebellar ataxia); dissemination in space and time; no NMJ findings
differential.tests: MRI brain/spine; LP (oligoclonal bands); no AChR antibodies

differential.features: Severe weakness, tachycardia, fever, agitation, lid lag; thyroid hormone excess
Episodic weakness triggered by meals, exercise, rest; normal between attacks
differential.tests: Serum potassium during attack; genetic testing

differential.features: Non-physiologic weakness; Hoover sign; distractible; no fatigable pattern
differential.tests: Normal NCS/EMG; normal antibodies; clinical exam

disposition.criteria: Exacerbation resolved; FVC >60% predicted and stable; able to swallow safely; adequate oral medications; no respiratory distress; stable immunotherapy regimen; follow-up within 1-2 weeks
Moderate exacerbation; FVC 20-30 mL/kg; requires IVIG or PLEX; dysphagia requiring modified diet; unable to maintain medications orally
Myasthenic crisis; FVC <20 mL/kg or declining rapidly; intubated; bulbar weakness with aspiration risk; post-operative thymectomy with respiratory concerns
Need for PLEX not available; neuromuscular specialist consultation; need for ICU with neurology expertise
Significant weakness; unable to perform ADLs independently; able to tolerate 3h/day therapy
